title: Adlecti
text:
During the <a href="Roman%20Kingdom">Roman Kingdom</a>, <a href="Roman%20Republic">Roman Republic</a> and later, adlecti, or allecti were those who were chosen to fill up a vacancy in any office or <a href="collegium%20%28ancient%20Rome%29">collegium</a>, and especially those who were chosen to fill up the proper number of the <a href="Roman%20Senate">senate</a>. As these would be generally <a href="Equestrian%20%28Roman%29">equites</a>, <a href="Sextus%20Pompeius%20Festus">Festus</a> defines the "adlecti" to be equites added to the senate: and he appears in this passage to make a distinction between the "adlecti" and the "<a href="conscripti">conscripti</a>". This distinction is supported by the summons form used to call the senate which reads "pares" and "conscripti" beginning in 509 BC. Others argue that they were the same; for in another passage, Festus gives the same definition of the conscripti as he had done of the adlecti, and <a href="Livy">Livy</a> (ii.1) says "conscriptos in novum senatum appellabant lectos".
The adelecti were also those persons under the <a href="Roman%20Empire">empire</a> who were admitted to the privileges and honours of the <a href="praetor">praetor</a>ship, <a href="quaestor">quaestor</a>ship, <a href="aedile">aedile</a>ship, and other public offices, without having any duties to perform ("Historia Augusta", "Helvius Pertinax", 6). In inscriptions we constantly find, "adlectus inter tribunos", "inter quaestores", "inter praetores", etc.
